nm</wcs:label>  <wcs:lonLatEnvelope srsName="urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84">   <gml:pos dimension="2">-179.500000 -89.500000</gml:pos>   <gml:pos dimension="2">179.500000 89.500000</gml:pos>  </wcs:lonLatEnvelope> </wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:description>  The OMI total NO2 column at 0.25x0.25 degree global grids, are the averages of all good quality observations that fall in a grid. In averaging the observations in a grid, weightings are assigned that depend on the cloud coverage and the size of the field of view, more weight is assigned to the near clear scenes and smaller field of views (near nadir). Since early 2007, OMI signals for some pixels across the track, started showing noticeable contamination, likely attributed to a piece of thermal insulation material started getting in the way of instrument optics. These scenes have been assigned fill values which appear as streaks in the maps that parallel the satellite's ground track. For the updates and related data products and documents, visit the GES DISC OMI data product site http://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/Aura/OMI/. </wcs:description> <wcs:name>OMNO2d:ColumnAmountNO2</wcs:name> <wcs:label>NO2 vertical column density</wcs:label>  <wcs:lonLatEnvelope srsName="urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84">   <gml:pos dimension="2">-179.875000 90.125000</gml:pos>   <gml:pos dimension="2">179.875000 -90.125000</gml:pos>  </wcs:lonLatEnvelope> </wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:description>Temporally averaged over the requested time for this product:   The OMI total NO2 column at 0.25x0.25 degree global grids, are the averages of all good quality observations that fall in a grid. In averaging the observations in a grid, weightings are assigned that depend on the cloud coverage and the size of the field of view, more weight is assigned to the near clear scenes and smaller field of views (near nadir). Since early 2007, OMI signals for some pixels across the track, started showing noticeable contamination, likely attributed to a piece of thermal insulation material started getting in the way of instrument optics. These scenes have been assigned fill values which appear as streaks in the maps that parallel the satellite's ground track. For the updates and related data products and documents, visit the GES DISC OMI data product site http://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/Aura/OMI/. </wcs:description> <wcs:name>OMNO2d:ColumnAmountNO2_timeAveraged</wcs:name> <wcs:label>Temporally averaged over the requested time of the NO2 vertical column density</wcs:label>  <wcs:lonLatEnvelope srsName="urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84">   <gml:pos dimension="2">-179.875000 90.125000</gml:pos>   <gml:pos dimension="2">179.875000 -90.125000</gml:pos>  </wcs:lonLatEnvelope> </wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:description>  The OMI Total NO2 column (cloud screened at 30%) at 0.25x0.25 degree global grids, are the averages of all good quality observations that fall in a grid. Only those observations are averaged that are either cloud free or cloud fraction is less than 30%. When any partial cloudy scene is considered, no assumed value of "below cloud NO2 column" (also referred as "ghost column") is added to the observed NO2 column.  In averaging the observations in a grid, weightings are assigned that depend on the cloud coverage and the size of the field of view, more weight is assigned to the near clear scenes and smaller field of views (near nadir).  Since early 2007, OMI signals for some pixels across the track, started showing noticeable contamination, likely attributed to a piece of thermal insulation material started getting in the way of instrument optics. These scenes have been assigned fill values which appear as streaks in the maps that parallel the satellite's ground track. For the updates and related data products, documents, visit the GES DISC OMI data product site http://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/Aura/OMI/. </wcs:description> <wcs:name>OMNO2d:ColumnAmountNO2CloudScreened</wcs:name> <wcs:label>NO2 vertical column density, screened for CloudFraction < 30%</wcs:label>  <wcs:lonLatEnvelope srsName="urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84">   <gml:pos dimension="2">-179.875000 90.125000</gml:pos>   <gml:pos dimension="2">179.875000 -90.125000</gml:pos>  </wcs:lonLatEnvelope> </wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:description>Temporally averaged over the requested time for this product:   The OMI Total NO2 column (cloud screened at 30%) at 0.25x0.25 degree global grids, are the averages of all good quality observations that fall in a grid. Since early 2007, OMI signals for some pixels across the track, started showing noticeable contamination, likely attributed to a piece of thermal insulation material started getting in the way of instrument optics. These scenes have been assigned fill values which appear as streaks in the maps that parallel the satellite's ground track. For the updates and related data products and documents, visit the GES DISC OMI data product site http://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/Aura/OMI/. </wcs:description> <wcs:name>OMNO2d:ColumnAmountNO2TropCloudScreened_timeAveraged</wcs:name> <wcs:label>Temporally averaged over the requested time of the NO2 tropospheric column density, screened for CloudFraction < 30%</wcs:label>  <wcs:lonLatEnvelope srsName="urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84">   <gml:pos dimension="2">-179.875000 90.125000</gml:pos>   <gml:pos dimension="2">179.875000 -90.125000</gml:pos>  </wcs:lonLatEnvelope> </wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:CoverageOfferingBrief> <wcs:description>Total Column Density of SO2 in the Planetary Boundary Layer (PBL,) based on an improved Band Residual Difference Algorithm (BRD).
